Replace.Text: Gain a Technology upon capturing a Settlement for the first time. Codices are not awarded from Technologies. Can generate Codices from Conquest after completing the Tupšarrūtu Civic.

[BLIST][LI]Gain a [B]Technology [/B]upon capturing a Settlement for the first time. [LI][B]Codices [/B]are not awarded from Technologies.[LI]Can generate [B]Codices[/B] from Conquest after completing the Tupšarrūtu Civic.[LI][B]+30%[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production [/B]towards constructing [B]Dur-Sharrukin[/B].[/LIST]
+30%[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production from being the Assyria's associated Wonder.

Ashur is a god, a land, and a city, all in one – the name “Assyria” is a Greek version of “mat Ashur,” or “the land of [the god-city of] Ashur.” It was one of the most significant and forward-looking empires of the ancient world. Its spread extended across Mesopotamia, including brief conquests in (what would become) Persia and (what already was) Egypt.

To begin, we must look at Sumerian history. The Sumerians were a rather mysterious people who appeared at the dawn of cities, possibly from the Indian subcontinent. They built some of the earliest cities in what is today Iraq. Over time, the Akkadians under Sargon rebelled and established an empire over former Sumerian lands, only to falter and collapse around 2150 BCE. The centuries following this fall were dark, with city-states (including Ashur) fighting for supremacy.

Assyria was to rise twice: first in the mid-1300s BCE and later, c. 900 BCE (for reference, this is younger than Egypt, but far older than Greece; at the tail end of Shang China and the rise of Zhou China). Here, we focus on the later Neo-Assyrian Empire.

The names of Sargon II, Sennacherib, Ashurbanipal, and other Assyrian kings are legendary for good reason – these were rulers who expanded the meaning of power across the region. This success was partly owed to a few novel experiments in economy – Assyria early on adopted a form of free trade (trade in Sumeria, by contrast, was managed via temples), but most significant was the development of a standing army. Think of this – soldiers no longer had to think about returning home to their fields at harvest time…meaning that they could sit outside of enemy fields waiting for their opponents to get exhausted. Furthermore, the Assyrians were engineers, having a dedicated engineering corps in the army that could build siege weapons, massive ramps, or other machines to make short work of ancient walls. Finally, the Assyrians were an Iron Age empire – iron is weaker than bronze (depending on its steel content), but could be mass-produced (and was not vulnerable to trade fluctuations; the older Assyrian Empire fell victim to some of the disruptions of the Late Bronze Age collapse). Even little innovations such as the combat boot come from Assyria – in short, the Assyrian army was a war machine.

And it was terrible. Assyrian accounts take particular pleasure in describing the horrors inflicted upon those who stood in their way – flayings, butcherings, and the utter destruction of cities that resisted them. Sennacherib’s conquests into Judah made it into the Old Testament – as Judah rebelled with Egyptian support, Sennacherib responded mercilessly, removing the entire population and torturing the leaders to death. As the captives were led into subjugation in Babylon, accounts report that the Assyrian armies forced them to sing songs of joy. The Biblical account holds that in the following siege of Jerusalem, divine vengeance was inflicted upon the invading Assyrians, though it may simply have been reports that Babylon had rebelled that caused the invaders to retreat.

At home, Sennacherib’s gardens were famous, marvels of hydroengineering that likely were the inspiration behind the “hanging gardens.” This, too, was about power – Assyrian gardens were models of conquest, with the landscape sculpted and fauna selected to reflect those of conquered lands. One could walk through the cedars of Lebanon “at home” and revel in the memory of its subjugation.

Ashurbanipal was the ultimate Assyrian king – meaning “the greatest” (arguably), but also the last (nearly). His father divided the kingdom between Ashur and Babylon for his two sons, but Ashurbanipal’s brother (who received the Babylonian portion) sought to ally instead with the Elamites and take the whole thing. This didn’t go well – Ashurbanipal destroyed his brother and Elam both (as well as conquering Egypt). His conquests were depicted in bas-reliefs complete with images of floating corpses. His cruelty, too, was depicted in the bas-reliefs of his lion hunt, a feat so brutal that the artist carved the animals in the extremity of their suffering, throwing back the image of the proud conqueror king.

Ashurbanipal was not simply a conqueror, though – he was literate, and his library was his pride. He gathered all the texts he could, of all varieties and genres, to preserve the knowledge of his era. Tens of thousands of clay tablets from his collection have survived in the ruins of Nineveh. Indeed, it is from his library that we find the Epic of Gilgamesh.

Assyrian society was multilingual, with Akkadian and Sumerian both present in various forms. Each city had its own patron god, and warfare was thought to be conducted not just between kings, but between these particular gods as well. Upon capture, a city would surrender its patron deity (e.g. Marduk, of Babylon) and the conquering deity might subject the conquered to a kind of ritual humiliation, or simply incorporate that deity in as a lesser member of a pantheon. Vassals, too, might remain or might find themselves replaced by Assyrian nobles – something that bred resentment amongst conquered peoples.

Resettlement was also vital to Assyrian conquest, laying the seeds of cultural shift. As Aramaic speakers were displaced across the empire, Aramaic became a new lingua franca, one that was to survive when the empire did not.
Assyria fell shortly after Ashurbanipal’s reign, though the particular reasons are unclear – signs point to environmental as well as social collapse, and a new Babylon rose in its ashes.

The Assyrian ekallu, or palace, was a complex for both royal residence and political function. They were imposing centers that balanced public and private spaces – they included reception halls and a throne room for visitors, administrative offices for officials, and gardens and dwellings for the king and his family. Buildings were richly decorated according to each space’s intended audience. Statues of creatures like lions and human-animal hybrids flanked gates and entrances, and painted reliefs adorned the walls. In diplomatic spaces, their subjects were royal in nature, such as court scenes and lion hunts, while private spaces focused on mythological or religious sequences.

The Neo-Assyrian king Ashurbanipal is well-known for his brutality in war; but he was also deeply invested in the collection and preservation of literature. The languages of ancient Mesopotamia were written in cuneiform scripts, the characters of which were pressed into clay tablets by means of a reed pen. Ashurbanipal, whose reliefs often depict him with a stylus, gathered these tablets at his palace and sent requests to neighboring kingdoms for more. Surviving works include, most famously, the Epic of Gilgamesh, but also letters, political documents, medical manuals, instructions for religious rituals, and more, all of which offer insight into the inner workings of Assyria through the voices of Assyrians themselves.

The collection of over 30,000 tablets now called the Royal Library of Ashurbanipal was first discovered in the 19th century. Tablets have been found at other palaces, indicating the existence of additional royal libraries, though not in the quantity uncovered at Nineveh.

The power of the Assyrian Empire lay in its centralization, which occurred on a scale that had not been seen before in history. The system of governance hinged on a single king whose word was law – it was not unusual for royal demands sent to even the most powerful governors to end with a threat of death, and perhaps that of the governor’s family, should he fail to deliver by the requested date. This kind of tight control was made possible through several factors of organization, including communication infrastructure, a highly trained standing army, the dispersal of opposition through population relocation, and the distribution of provincial authority. But all of it stemmed from the core, run from the king’s citadel at the heart of his capital.

The Assyrian army was the most effective military force in the world, and was highly skilled at siege warfare. Their conquests came through the use of siege weapons, earthen ramps, and psychological warfare in addition to their well-trained troops and efficient tactics. Thus the Assyrians were well-informed when it came to building their own fortified cities (birtūtu). A combination of towers and thick crenelated walls offered protection to those within, while moats and ramps could be effectively defended from above. Gates, always a fortress’s weakest points, were not only physically tough, but were richly decorated with mythic creatures and martial reliefs to intimidate invaders and visitors alike.

Education in the Assyrian Empire began early for children seeking to become scribes. Over the course of 12 years, boys and girls were rigorously trained in cuneiform script; they also studied topics ranging from history and religion to medicine and agriculture. This form of scribal scholarship – tupšarrūtu – was intensive and challenging for students. But once they graduated, they became highly sought after for their skills, eligible for any position that required literacy and education, including scribes, doctors, astronomers, musicians, and architects.

Royal inscriptions of ancient Mesopotamian rulers typically begin with a list of titles, and among the Neo-Assyrian kings, one of the most potent is “king of the four quarters.” The four quarters, “kibrāt arba’i,” refer to ancient geographical locations that align with the cardinal directions (Sumer, Martu, Elam, and Subartu), but the implication is “the whole world.” It is not used by every king – its presence declines with the absence of military campaigns, so certain military accomplishments may have been required to claim it. Its potency outlived the Assyrians themselves; the final ruler to use the title was Cyrus the Great.

A turtānu was a high-ranking military official who led the Assyrian army in place of the king in times of war. It was an immensely powerful position, second only to that of the ruler. At some point in the eighth century BCE, the position seems to have been divided in two, one turtānu for “the right” and one for “the left,” possibly to decrease the amount of power held by one person other than the king. Over time their duties shifted from purely martial to include civil governance of regional territories.

“Magarru” means chariot, a key weapon within the Neo-Assyrian army. Although horses had been in use in Mesopotamia since at least the Akkadian Empire, the lack of saddles, stirrups, and other equipment made them difficult to ride effectively in war. They were more easily managed when harnessed to chariots. These vehicles were small and light, possessing two wheels and carrying two passengers, a driver and an archer. Because horses are naturally averse to charging at lines of soldiers, they were saved until the enemy was about, or had begun, to flee – then the chariots were deployed to swiftly deliver the archer to his quarry.

The downside of chariots was that they were expensive to produce, and so using them on the field was a financial risk. But by the reign of Sargon II, in the eight century BCE, horse tack and horsemanship began to improve, and soon cavalry surpassed chariots as the army’s mobile unit.

Assyrian Unique Quarter. Created by constructing the Royal Library and Citadel in the same District. +2 [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production for each [icon:NAR_REW_GREATWORK] Great Work in this Settlement.
+2 [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production for each [icon:NAR_REW_GREATWORK] Great Work in this Settlement.
+3[icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science. Has 2 Codex slots. +1[icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science Adjacency for Rivers and Wonders. Assyrian Unique Science Building. Ageless.
Has 2 Codex slots. Assyrian Unique Science Building. Ageless.

+3 [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production. +2[icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness if placed on Flat Terrain. +1[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production adjacency for Wonders. Assyrian Unique Production Building and Fortification. Ageless. All Fortified Districts must be conquered to capture a Settlement.
+2[icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness if placed on Flat Terrain. Assyrian Unique Production Building and Fortification. Ageless. All Fortified Districts must be conquered to capture a Settlement.
"The city's wall I established firm as the mountains, and peoples of the land which my hands had conquered, I settled therein."
"You, O Assur, hold all knowledge from the ancient past to the distant future."
"I led my armies from one end of the earth to the other and brought into submission all princes of the four quarters."
The Capital receives 2 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture for each Technology Mastery.
Combat units receive +5 Combat Strength when defending against Ranged units.
When you capture a Settlement for the first time receive a Codex.
+5 Combat Strength to Magarru if they are in a Command Radius.
+20% [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science in Cities not founded by you.
+25% [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production towards Buildings and Wonders with a Great Work Slot.
+3 [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production and [icon:YIELD_FOOD] Food in Settlements not founded by you.

Siege-towers rumble, and iron swords are sharpened as the Assyrian war machine shudders into motion. Under Ashur’s watchful eye, a new order unfolds upon the sun-baked clay: planned cities, skilled engineers, and the implacable march of boots. Set out upon the world, and tolerate no competition.
The people are summoned here, to the heartlands, where they will labor and thrive. And by the providence of Ashur their name will be Assyria.
Technology Masteries may not grant Assyria Codices, but they will grant Culture with the Birtūtu Civic. Unlock the Tupšarrūtu Civic quickly to get Codices from conquering Settlements instead!
Contains a new Antiquity Age Civilization, Assyria.
Assyrian heralds announce their right to rule as the šar kibrāt arba’i – the lords over the four corners of the world. But the meaning is open to interpretation.
It is literal. Strive towards conquest.
It is figurative. Strive towards knowledge.

A shopkeeper squeezes through the temple crowd towards her wares, stored safely under the eye of the priests. Surrounding her, other merchants press coins into the attendants’ hands, each eager to have their transactions recorded. Here, one may address issues of spirit and finance in one stop.
Priests should finance their own trade ventures.

Assyrian sappers assist the war engines, tearing loose bricks from the wall with hammers and pickaxes. When the dust clears, both engine crews and their commanders claim credit for the wall’s collapse.
This is the result of Assyrian engineering.
Let this be a lesson for Assyria's commanders.

The feeding of the god Ashur begins in the newly conquered city, and dejected lines form bearing gifts of cattle and grain to the altar. A priest of the old faith hangs back, refusing to acknowledge this new divine order, as an Assyrian commander looks on.
Ignore the priest. The time for mercy has come.
Select an additional Pantheon, but {1_reward} in all Settlements.
Draw weapons. Surrender must be absolute.
Army recruits sleep in stables, and commanders hold their meetings in the open air. There are simply too many soldiers and too few places for them.
A soldier's life is hard. They must adapt.

No one speaks when the commander leaves. Words mean little when a rising tide seems ready to drown Ashur and all his glory. The news of the recent defeat will trickle down to the rest of the Assyrian people soon.
Rekindle hope. The tide may yet turn.
Train more soldiers. The tide may yet turn.

A young woman practices inscribing her name onto soft clay. Though barely legible, it will act as the seal to bind herself to a temporary contract in search of a better life. One of servitude, but that is full of food, clothing, and warmth.
Destroy the tablet and return home. Servitude is no choice.
The library rises, its magnificence dwarfed by the worlds contained in the writings within. But there are too many empty shelves, too many spaces for yet more dreams inscribed in clay.
All texts, everywhere, belong to Assyria.
The librarian places the work in its seat of honor. She takes a small cloth and wipes clean a small stain. Ink, perhaps.
Use some of this empty space for local merchants.

The arena is adorned with images of lion hunts, and it is lions the crowd has come to see. As the lion is released, the crowd roars with joy. But as it concludes, the mournful howls of the wounded beast draw murmurs of sympathy.
Spare the lions. Have soldiers fight.
A captured enemy commander is forced to his knees as Assyrian soldiers bring forth a chariot. After the humiliation on the battlefield, some further demonstration is needed.
The prisoner will pull the chariot through the city!
The prisoner will neigh like a proper steed.
The Good Doctor in the Land of Kings
Dr. Rizal regards an immense siege tower, its top just visible behind the wall of an Assyrian garrison, and a chill runs down the length of his spine.

The world contains innumerable mysteries waiting to be discovered, but many of them are selfishly hoarded by Assyria’s enemies. As your humble Science Advisor, I believe no cost is too great in the pursuit of knowledge. Let us begin by learning our own strength.

Objective: [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]Study {LOC_CIVIC_BIRTUTU_NAME} and {LOC_CIVIC_DISCIPLINE_NAME}[/b], the first step towards establishing a [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science Legacy of the Antiquity Age. [n][n]Remember: [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] [b]Legacies [/b]improve your performance in later Ages, but [b]you can choose to pursue one, multiple, or none at all[/b].

I am no fighter, but it is clear that Assyria is as fierce as a pride of lions. We will need our mightiest to wrest the secrets of the world from others’ covetous hands. Gather your troops and prepare for battle.

As [b]Assyria[/b], you may only acquire Codices through [b]Settlement capture [/b]and the [b]Assyria [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] Civic tree[/b]. Unlike other Civilizations, you will need to create a strong military to progress upon this Legacy Path. [n]Next Objective: Study [icon:NOTIFICATION_CULTURE_TREE_REVEALED] [b]{LOC_CIVIC_TUPSARRUTU_NAME}[/b], which will allow you to get a [b]Codex [/b]upon capturing a Settlement. Then, pack a {1_ArmyCommanderIcon} [b]{2_ArmyCommanderName} with Units [/b]to create a military force.
A pride of lions indeed. Now, remember what I have said – no cost is too great in the pursuit of knowledge. Go to our enemies, and bring back our rightful spoils.
Next Objective: [b]Capture any Settlement[/b], creating a [b]Codex[/b]: a Great Work of the Antiquity Age.
From the fires of war comes the light that will guide our people forward. [n]But I believe that this is only the beginning. Continue our crusade for knowledge, and prepare a place to enshrine it.

Codices must be [b]displayed [/b]to count towards the [icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] [b]{LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science Legacy Path, the Assyrian [icon:BUILDING_ROYAL_LIBRARY] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_ROYAL_LIBRARY_NAME} [/b]can be built in any City and has slots to [b]display [/b]your Codices. [n]Next Objective: Build a [icon:BUILDING_ROYAL_LIBRARY] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_ROYAL_LIBRARY_NAME} [/b], then earn and display [b]{1_CodexGoalNum} Codices[/b].
{1_CodexCount} Codices now grace our halls of learning, containing the collected knowledge of the Assyrian people. What secrets yet elude us?

You have achieved the first [b]Milestone [/b]in the [b]{LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path[/b]! [n]Next Objective: build a second [icon:BUILDING_ROYAL_LIBRARY] [b]{LOC_BUILDING_ROYAL_LIBRARY_NAME} [/b]to house more Codices, then [b]display {1_CodexGoalNum} Codices[/b], the second Milestone along this Legacy Path.
We now possess {1_CodexCount} Codices. Assyrian wisdom grows by the day, and the darkness of ignorance recedes ever further.

You have achieved the second great [b]Milestone [/b]in the [b]{LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path[/b]! Continue to collect [b]Codices [/b]to earn the last group of rewards. [n]Next Objective: [b]display {1_CodexGoalNum} Codices[/b], achieving the third and [b]final [/b]Milestone in the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} Legacy Path.

Our collection of Codices is the envy of the world, a veritable garden of knowledge that will bear fruit for ages to come. The mysteries of the universe are innumerable, but we should regard our work with pride.

Congratulations! You've [b]displayed {1_CodexCount} Codices [/b]and successfully completed the [b][icon:NOTIFICATION_TEAM_VICTORIOUS] {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_ANTIQUITY_SCIENCE_NAME} [/b][icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science Legacy Path of the Antiquity Age. [n]You can visit the [b]Legacy Path Screen [/b]to see more Legacy Paths you can follow, or you can forge your own path.
Assyrian Unique Cavalry Unit. Moves like a wheeled unit and has additional Movement. Can move after attacking and ignores Zone of Control.
Can move after attacking and ignores Zone of Control.
Tier 2 Assyrian Unique Cavalry Unit. Moves like a wheeled unit and has additional movement. Can move after attacking and ignores Zone of Control.
Tier 3 Assyrian Unique Cavalry Unit. Moves like a wheeled unit and has additional Movement. Can move after attacking and ignores Zone of Control.
Assyrian Unique Army Commander. Infantry and Cavalry units within the Command Radius have +5 Combat Strength against Districts.
Infantry and Cavalry units within the Command Radius have +5 Combat Strength against Districts.
[B]Lakshmibai[/B] was from the same continent as [B]Assyria[/B].
[B]Xerxes[/B] ruled the region that was once [B]Assyria[/B].
As Assyria, complete a Scientific Legacy Path
